text: Again, an usual last name (which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book). It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Toker's essay, "Gamesman's Sketches (Found in a Bottle)," CASS 21.3-4: 356). Еще одна необычная фамилия (которая встречается и в других графических-орфографических вариантов дальше в тексте). Намекается на сказку Золушки (по-английски Cinderella; cм. L. Toker, "Gamesman's Sketches (Found in a Bottle)," CASS 21.3-4: 356).
In the gospels Peter (and his brother Andrew) was invited by Jesus to become a "fisher of men"
Colloquial: smart aleck

In ancient Russia, a sloboda referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, sloboda refers to a rural locality various oblasts.
He find seasonal jobs. Занимается сезонной работой.

A misspelling of дрожжи (yeast)As Mario Caramitti noted in his doctoral dissertation (2001), Krylobyl represents an hypostasis of the poet Drozhzhin (recalled here through the misspelled "yeast"), the first Russian translator of Rilke, who lived on an island later on submerged by the Volga, situated in front of the little house Sokolov lived in during his time passed at Bezborodovo.

Bookish: to take out

A reference to the missing letter *zhe* in the word дрожжи (yeast), misspelled as дрозжи. Boguslawski suggests that the "significance of the letter Zh depends less on its being a part of the word drozzhi (yeast; pronounced drozhzhi), but more on being the initial letter of the words zhizn’ (life) and zhenshchina (woman), two mysteries the narrators try to clarify and explain throughout the novel" (Boguslawski, "Annotations" 238).
Low style/colloquial: to delay, stump, cause a delay
In this discussion of various letters, Ilya alludes to Saints Cyril and Methodius, known as the "славянские просветители" (Slavic enlighteners).
Pyotr suggests that the letter г (g) resembles the gallows. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f4/Tombstone_courthouse_gallows.jpg)

text: That is, on the gallows, people can only make sputtering, choking sounds.In this passage Pyotr is somehow discussing the arbitrariness of our writing systems and of alphabets in general (something linguists have long debated, see for example Saussure's disquisition on the arbitrary relation between the signifier and the signified), linking grapheme to phoneme in a logical (at least, to him) manner. This is just one more way of stressing the central role played by language itself in the structuring of the whole novel.

text: Ostanin (35) notes that in Chapter 1 we encountered the toponym Bydogoshchi, which recalls the existing village of Vidogoshchi situated by the Volga river. So "b" is indeed almost a "v".

text: We should also consider the fact that this letter lacks a univocal corresponding grapheme in the Latin or Greek alphabets, and it is not known how this character was derived. Moreover, the use of the term "zagadochna" may recall the famous concept of the supposed "mysterious Russian soul" (zagadochnaya russkaya dusha). Following this, we could consider the letter "zhe" here as an objectivation of "Russianness" and, therefore, of the supposed "Russian mysteriousness".

text: Ilya frequently compares himself to the prophet Elijah, whose name day—July 20 Old Style / August 2 New Style—marks the transition from summer to fall. Ostanin indicates that this is also a reference to the following proverb: "Петр и Павел час убавил, а Илья Пророк два уволок" (Peter and Paul stole an hour, and Ilya the Prophet took away two) (Ostanin 35). The exact quantities are not actually correct, but the meaning is that on these saints respective days (July 12 and August 2) the sun moves faster than on the longest days of summer.

Ukranian: cooper. Another form, бочар, appears in chapter 3 (R164/E28).
Ilya is referring to his damaged sharpening wheel, but ущербной may also refer to the waning moon, a key image in the novel, as seen in the opening line.

Ostanin identifies this as an allusion to Mikhail Lermontov's 1837 poem "Borodino": "Что ж мы? на зимние квартиры?" (Ostanin 35). Read the poem and an English translation [here](https://ruverses.com/mikhail-lermontov/borodino/1830/).

Rainy weather or a long rain during hay season that will bring rot. Maybe also refer to long rainy weather in spring, summer, or autumn. Also refers to St. Samson's day (June 27 OS / July 10 NS). As Boguslawski writes, folk tradition holds that on this date "the rains begin, which often continue for a week, causing the cut but not gathered hay to rot. For this reason, the saint is often called Sampson the Hay-rot" (Boguslawski, "Annotations" 238).

text: Literal: fish fur. Set expression meaning poor-quality winter-weather clothing. Derived from the Russian proverb "A poor man's fur coat is of fish fur" (У бедняка шуба на рыбьем меху). Such furs were used by the Soviet Army; given the number and kinds of wounds on display by the residents of the novel's community, it can be assumed that many of them are veterans. Today, the phrase also refers to fake fur.

text: This phraseologism is generally used to describe a person with an unstable character.
